block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

Democrats Weigh Answer To Veto of War Funding Bill The Senate sent President Bush a war spending measure he has promised to veto, forcing Democrats to confront the question of what to do after the president acts.
A1

Russia to Suspend Arms Treaty Russia's president said his country would stop complying with a treaty on conventional arms in Europe that was forged at the end of the cold war, underscoring the Kremlin's anger at an American proposal for a missile defense system in Europe.
A1

French Rivals Exchange Barbs The Socialist candidate in the French presidential election accused her opponent of having ''apologized'' to President Bush for France's decision not to take part in the Iraq war. A10
Both candidates are members of unconventional couples. The Socialist candidate is not married to the father of her four children, and the conservative candidate and his wife are often apart.
A1

Serious Charge for Ranking G.I. The American military has charged a top commander at Camp Cropper near Baghdad with violations of military law, including ''aiding the enemy,'' a serious accusation that could carry a death sentence.
World Bank Team Complains Members of the World Bank's anti-corruption team said the controversy over Paul Wolfowitz's conduct was undermining their work.
A6
Afghanistan Infant Deaths Drop Health officials said that Afghan infant mortality has dropped by 18 percent.
NATIONAL A18-25

Dean at M.I.T. Resigns After Lying on Résumé The dean of admissions at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Marilee Jones, who became famous for urging stressed-out students competing for elite colleges to calm down and stop trying to be perfect, has resigned after admitting that she had fabricated her own educational credentials.
A1

Concerns Over Warming Issues Americans in large bipartisan numbers say the heating of the earth's atmosphere is having serious effects on the environment now or will soon and think that it is necessary to take immediate steps to reduce its effects, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds.

Bush Criticized by Candidates The eight Democratic presidential candidates used their first joint appearance to assail President Bush for threatening to veto legislation that would set a deadline for bringing troops out of Iraq. A24

New Bill on Buying Guns The Justice Department proposed legislation that would give the attorney general discretion to bar terrorism suspects from buying a firearm, seeking to close a controversial gap in federal gun laws.
SCIENCE/HEALTH

Genes Linked to Diabetes Researchers said they had identified seven new genes connected to the most common form of diabetes, the latest result of an intensifying race to find genes linked to a range of diseases. A22
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6

Slain Trooper Took Part In Another Deadly Manhunt David C. Brinkerhoff, the New York State trooper who was fatally shot by a fugitive this week, spent days tracking Ralph J. Phillips, another fugitive who had shot and killed a trooper, before Mr. Phillips was captured last September. B1
Bloomberg Proposes Budget Mayor Bloomberg proposed a $59 billion budget that maintains tax cuts he promised earlier this year and includes a record-setting $4.4 billion surplus. B1
Sincerely, George Washington A letter written by George Washington in May or July of 1787 was recently discovered in a brown leather scrapbook started by a young New Jersey girl in 1826. B1
BUSINESS DAY C1-9
Losses Shrink at Ford Ford Motor announced a $282 million loss in the first quarter. Company officials said the loss, much smaller than last year's, was proof that a restructuring plan was working.
C1

Investors Get Into the Deal The $8 billion private equity buyout of Harman International Industries, the maker of speakers and home theater systems, breaks new ground by offering shareholders a chance to share in profits made if the company is sold or taken public again.
C1
Business Digest C2
OBITUARIES C10-11
Jack Valenti A confidant of President Lyndon B. Johnson and a Hollywood institution, he was 85. C10
EDITORIAL A26-27
Editorials: After the lawyers; crippling government from within; Corporal Tillman haunts the Pentagon; Dorothy Samuels on the new abortion ruling and the Roberts court.
Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Paul Krugman.
